introduce.title: Introducing Grunfeld
introduce.description:
Grunfeld is a lightweight library that makes it easy and consistent to manage dialogs (modals, alerts, confirmations, etc.) in React applications. It's designed to allow you to display dialogs for user interaction and handle results with just a few lines of declarative code, without cumbersome state management or complex control flow.



The core goals are simplicity, accessibility, and extensibility. It supports accessibility considerations by default, such as focus trapping, keyboard dismissal, and ARIA attributes, and allows you to easily change appearance and behavior with custom components, handle multiple modal stacks, integrate animation hooks. It provides a Promise-based API to naturally handle asynchronous flows (e.g., waiting for user decisions in confirmation dialogs).



It also provides TypeScript-friendly type definitions to help you use it safely at compile time, and maintains consistent dialog behavior across your application through the Context/Provider pattern. In server-side rendering (SSR) environments, it's designed to safely render fallback UI, clearly separating client-only logic. It's suitable for teams that want to implement complex dialog scenarios with concise code while maintaining accessibility and maintainability.

basic-usage.title: Basic Usage
basic-usage.0: Grunfeld provides two main usage patterns: simple alerts and dialogs that receive user responses. Each pattern is implemented using different overloads.
basic-usage.1: Using a factory function without parameters creates a simple alert. This approach returns <cd>void</cd> and executes synchronously.
basic-usage.2: Confirmation dialogs that wait for user selection receive the <cd>removeWith</cd> function as a parameter. Call this function to close the dialog and return a result value.
basic-usage.3: Dialogs that receive data input from users follow the same pattern. Create an input component and pass the value through <cd>removeWith</cd>.

dialog-patterns.title: Dialog Patterns
dialog-patterns.0: Grunfeld supports various dialog patterns. Each pattern is optimized for specific use cases.
dialog-patterns.1: A simple alert that conveys information to the user. It has no return value and provides only a confirmation button.
dialog-patterns.2: Used when a user decision is required. Typically returns a boolean value.
dialog-patterns.3: Receives text input from the user. Returns the entered string.
dialog-patterns.4: Use custom components when complex UI or multi-step interaction is required.

add-method.title: grunfeld.add()
add-method.0: The <cd>grunfeld.add()</cd> method is the core API for creating new dialogs. It provides two overloads to support various use cases.
add-method.1: Using a factory function without parameters creates a simple alert:
add-method.2: This overload returns <cd>void</cd> and executes immediately. You can return a React element directly or return a <cd>GrunfeldProps</cd> object.
add-method.3: Using a factory function that receives the <cd>removeWith</cd> parameter allows you to receive user responses:
add-method.4: This overload returns <cd>Promise'<'T | undefined'>'</cd>. When the user calls <cd>removeWith(value)</cd>, the Promise resolves with that value.

list.0: <cd>element</cd>: The React element to display in the dialog
list.2: <cd>lightDismiss</cd>: Whether to close on backdrop click (default: true)
list.5: <cd>dismissCallback</cd>: Callback executed when the dialog closes

add-method.6: When a dialog is forcibly closed by <cd>grunfeld.remove()</cd> or <cd>grunfeld.clear()</cd>, the Promise resolves with <cd>undefined</cd>:

remove-clear.title: remove & clear
remove-clear.0: Grunfeld provides two methods for removing dialogs.
remove-clear.1: Removes the most recently added dialog. Dialogs are removed in LIFO (Last In First Out) order:
remove-clear.2: This method resolves the dialog's Promise with <cd>undefined</cd>. When multiple dialogs are stacked, only the topmost dialog is removed.
remove-clear.4: This method resolves all dialogs' Promises with <cd>undefined</cd>. Useful in emergencies or during route changes.
remove-clear.5: Users can also close dialogs using the following methods:

list.0: ESC Key: Closes the most recent dialog (same as grunfeld.remove())
list.1: Backdrop Click: Closes the dialog if lightDismiss: true

remove-clear.6: These user actions also resolve the Promise with <cd>undefined</cd>.

render-modes.0: Grunfeld supports two rendering modes: <cd>inline</cd> and <cd>top-layer</cd>. Each mode has different advantages and disadvantages.
